It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its vibrant, showy inflorescences. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are usually alternate, simple, and have a rough texture. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils.

It thrives in humid, lowland areas with well-drained soils. This species is commonly found in secondary forests and along riverbanks. It prefers partial to full sunlight and is often associated with disturbed habitats. Due to its limited range, it is considered a rare and endemic plant in these regions.
